JAY CAGERS TO PLAY
CATHOLIC UNIVERSITY

Jays Are Slow

Past Experiences

During the first 15 minutes, the
Jays were unable to do any considerable amount of shooting and
the fast working Maryland five were
able to gain a 11-2 lead in the first
fifteen minutes of play. At the
end of the half, the Terps were on
the long end of the 26-7 score.

If past scores and results mean
anything, the Jays ought to be able
to add one more game to their list
of victories for the cage season
which is fast drawing to a close.
The Catholic U team has not had a
very successful season when judged
from the standpoint of games won.
Only a few weeks ago, they lost a
heart-breaking game to Baltimore
University by a score of 32-28. Not
until the very end of the game, was
one able to say which team would
come off the court as the victor. The
game ended in a tie and an extra
period was necessary, to decide the
winner.
The Jays have played Baltimore
U twice and defeated them both
times. They have also played and
defeated Catholic University. From
this angle, one might say that the
Jay team will be the victor, but it
is a had policy to endeavor to predict the outcome of any contest, and
we will therefore refrain from being prognosticators.

Jays Rally

The Jays came back in the second half with blood in their eyes
and during the first few minutes of
the second half, they literally swept
their opponents off their feet and
chalked up nine points in short order. All during the second half, it
was very evident that the Maryland
five had lost the wonderful co-ordination and smooth playing that
they had shown in the first stages of
play, and that the Jay five had
acquired, to some extent, the firey
playing of the Terps and an ability
to score goals, which had been lacking among the Hopkins quintet previously. The Jay defense, in the
second period, held the Maryland
five to a score just half as large as
the had rolled up in the first half,
while they themselves put on steam
and more than doubled their first
period score. However the lead was
too great to overcome and the Jays
went down to defeat, by a score of
39 to 24.

LACROSSE MEETING
HELD LAST FRIDAY

HOPKINS OBSERVES
54TH ANNIVERSARY
New Page School Head Makes
Principal Address
GOODNOW HONORED
Dr. Joseph S. Ames Inaugurated as University President
Hopkins' fifty-fourth birthday
was celebrated Saturday by exercises in the auditorium of the Peabody Institute and h. luncheon and
exhibition in Gilman Hall. At the
same time Dr. Joseph S. Ames was
formally inducted into the office of
President of the University as successor to Dr. Frank Johnson Goodnow, who received the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws following
the new president's inauguration.
Mr. John Van Antwerp MacMurray, recently American Minister to
China, a former Assistant Secretary
of State, and director of the new
Walter Hines Page School of International Relations, made the
scheduled address, and the rest of
the program was carried out as
printed in Friday's NEWS-LETTER.
The music was furnished by the
Johns Hopkins' Orchestra and the
ushers were members of the Hopkins R.O.T.C. unit.
Dr. Ames Comments

Dr. Ames, in his brief reply to the
remarks made by Blanchard Randall, speaking for the trustees in
the absence of their president, Daniel Willard, said that he had no
policy of action to outline, no novelties to advocate, and no promises
to make other than not to assume a
presidential attitude.
The president commented on the
spirit of Hopkins, which he defined
as "a consciousness of complete
academic freedom of thought and
action and a common purpose representing the ideals of the members of the facutly." In his judgment, Dr. Ames continued, the
president's first duty must be to
cherish this spirit.
His Purpose

The new president said he
thought the three principal requirements of a professor next to ability
in his field, were character, intellectual honesty, and personality. A
university president, he asserted,
ought to be enthusiastic, and it will
be easy for him to be as ever his
trustee, his faculty and his students.
His only purpose, he concluded, is
to cooperate with these groups to
make the University as great as it
is bound to be.
In presenting President Emeritus
Goodnow for the honorary degree,
Dr. W. W. Willoughby, professor
of political science, called him one
of the most distinguished political scientists of the day, stating
that he was recognized as such not
only in this country but also in
Europe.
The custom, formerly prevailing,
of conferring degrees upon students
at the Commemoration Day Exercises was not followed this year,
it being felt that such action was
more appropriate to the commencement exercises in June.
Speaker Enthusiastic

Mr. MacMurray said the Page
School, because it was attacking a
new field, would have to go slowly,
and might meet disappointments.
On the other hand, he was able to
voice enthusiasm for the work the
institution would do. Although it
may be impossible to hope for the
precision of physical sciences, the
director affirmed, "the very effort
to reduce to priciples the phenomena
of international relationships may
help to bring about a new conception of them . . . . as evolutions
along pre-determined lines.

EDITORIALS

EVENTS OF THE WEEK
EVERAL events of no small importance took place during the past
week-end. Matters concerning the fundamental policies of Johns
Hopkins were discussed by Dr. Ames and Mr. MacMurray at the Commemoration Day Exercises, two Hopkins men, Dr. Goodnow and
Sidney Lanier, were singularly honored, and the new library decorations were formally completed.
Dr. Ames again stressed the spirit of freedom at Johns Hopkins in
his speech at the Lyric Saturday. It has always been the policy of the
administrative officials to allow the members of the faculty to give
their courses in their own manner. Contrast this policy with that of
other universities, which do their best to attract brilliant professors
only to destroy this value by forcing them to conform strictly to
pedagogical principles. Hopkins allows its professors to retain their
individuality, to make decisions on matters which they alone are
qualified to judge, and endeavours to keep the members of the faculty
from becoming mere audible text-books. The restrictive principles
employed by most colleges tends to the treatment of ideas as though
they were parts of a Ford car; all thoughts are carefully examined
by the college officials and, if they conform to pre-conceived judgments, they are stamped "Approved" and allowed to be given to a
bored world. But if, Heaven forbid, some spark of originality should
enter into the minds of a member of the faculty it is promptly and
forcibly extinguished. We should rejoice that Hopkins allows men to
think for themselves and to impart their ideas to others without undergoing the fear of starving their wives and families by so doing.
John Van Antwerp MacMurray, the chairman of the Page School,
outlined the method of study which the school will pursue. Following
the Hopkins tradition, the research plan will be employed. Mr. MacMurray stressed the point that the study of national psychologies will
play a prominent part in the work of the school. The amalgamation
of two social sciences, political science and psychology, studied along
the lines usually reserved for the more exact sciences should prove an
• interesting experiment. The Page School undoubtedly will throw light
upon many of the problems of international relations; its practical
value will depend on to what extent the men who conduct diplomatic
and commercial intercourse between nations will allow themselves to
be influenced by the conclusions reached by the School.
The awarding of the degree of Doctor of Laws to President-Emeritus
Goodnow came as a fitting climax to his career at Johns Hopkins. No
man living has done more for the University; no man has carried out
finer projects at Hopkins; no man could more fittingly be honored by
Hopkins than Dr. Goodnow.

Rev. Frederick Trafford, Bethlehem Police Superintendent, has delivered an ultimatum to Lehigh students! War is declared on all youthful kleptomaniacs of the above mentioned shrine of learning, culture,
and the better and nobler things of
life. For Dr. F. H. Long, physician
of the neighboring metropolis of
Coopersburg, after suffering for
two years from the depreciations of
frat initiates who have seen fit to
possess themselves of his signs. So
now, he has declared that he is determined to prosecute future offenders. "To jail with collegiate sign
stealers!" is the battle cry to be
heard in the highways and byways
of the little town of Bethlehem. The
matter has been referred to the Interfraternity Council and immediate action is demanded. Warrants
for individual students will be
sworn in if necessary, and several
of the more active frats fear a
veritable reign of terror if the Police Superintendent makes good his
threat of issuing search warrants
for every Lehigh frat house. We
wish the Crusaders the best of
luck.

constantly studying new ways to make the
customer's dealings with the company
easy and pleasant. The new "counterless" idea, now being introduced in the
telephone company's business offices, is a
case in point.

the memory of another great Hopkins man. The collection of Lanier's
works placed in the Alcove will do much to perpetuate the name of
the Southern poet. Coincidental with the building of the Alcove, the
long-promised stained-glass windows were erected. They have been
promised for ten years, but the final result has been well worth waiting for.

Not a minor item of the book exhibit held last Saturday was the
newly decorated windows of the
Library. These windows, bearing
the marks of famous classic printers were decorated through the bequest of Mrs. Mary King Carey,
widow of Thomas G. Carey in memory of her father, Francis T. King.
King, the subject of the memoriam,
was one of the original trustees of
the Johns Hopkins Hospital.

corner of the room, the marked
windows run as follows: 1. Reginald

Dal Gesu, 5. Simon De Colines, 6.
Louis Elzivir, 7. Andre Wechel, 8.

10. Gutenberg, Fust, and Schoffer,
(fathers of modern printing), 11.
Oldus Manutius, 12. Christopher
Plantin, 13. Sebastian Gryphus, 14.

Track practice was initiated yesterday afternoon when the candidates for positions on this year's
team received their first official
workout on the cinder track. A
majority of last year's men are bask,
there being nine letter men from
last year. Schiebel will not be back
this year, due to the fact that he has
been running for Hopkins for four
years. Two of last year's letter
men have been blacklisted and accordingly will not be able to run.

be a well-balanced team this season
which begins in April. The first
meet is scheduled for April 12,
when Gettysburg will be the opponents. For the last week or so

to be in condition earlier.

Swimming Manager
Arranges Schedule
Junior Manager Cone of the
swimming team is arranging the
schedule for next year's natators.
The schedule will cover the months
of January and February, and will
probably embrace eight meets.
There will be one meet the first
week of January and a trip probably to northern territory, the second
week. Activities will be suspended
the next three weeks, due to examinations. During the last three
weeks of February, five or six meets
will be held.

JAY CAGERS TO PLAY
CATHOLIC UNIVERSITY

Jays Are Slow

Past Experiences

During the first 15 minutes, the
Jays were unable to do any considerable amount of shooting and
the fast working Maryland five were
able to gain a 11-2 lead in the first
fifteen minutes of play. At the
end of the half, the Terps were on
the long end of the 26-7 score.

If past scores and results mean
anything, the Jays ought to be able
to add one more game to their list
of victories for the cage season
which is fast drawing to a close.
The Catholic U team has not had a
very successful season when judged
from the standpoint of games won.
Only a few weeks ago, they lost a
heart-breaking game to Baltimore
University by a score of 32-28. Not
until the very end of the game, was
one able to say which team would
come off the court as the victor. The
game ended in a tie and an extra
period was necessary, to decide the
winner.
The Jays have played Baltimore
U twice and defeated them both
times. They have also played and
defeated Catholic University. From
this angle, one might say that the
Jay team will be the victor, but it
is a had policy to endeavor to predict the outcome of any contest, and
we will therefore refrain from being prognosticators.

Jays Rally

The Jays came back in the second half with blood in their eyes
and during the first few minutes of
the second half, they literally swept
their opponents off their feet and
chalked up nine points in short order. All during the second half, it
was very evident that the Maryland
five had lost the wonderful co-ordination and smooth playing that
they had shown in the first stages of
play, and that the Jay five had
acquired, to some extent, the firey
playing of the Terps and an ability
to score goals, which had been lacking among the Hopkins quintet previously. The Jay defense, in the
second period, held the Maryland
five to a score just half as large as
the had rolled up in the first half,
while they themselves put on steam
and more than doubled their first
period score. However the lead was
too great to overcome and the Jays
went down to defeat, by a score of
39 to 24.

HOPKINS OBSERVES
54TH ANNIVERSARY
New Page School Head Makes
Principal Address
GOODNOW HONORED
Dr. Joseph S. Ames Inaugurated as University President
Hopkins' fifty-fourth birthday
was celebrated Saturday by exercises in the auditorium of the Peabody Institute and h. luncheon and
exhibition in Gilman Hall. At the
same time Dr. Joseph S. Ames was
formally inducted into the office of
President of the University as successor to Dr. Frank Johnson Goodnow, who received the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws following
the new president's inauguration.
Mr. John Van Antwerp MacMurray, recently American Minister to
China, a former Assistant Secretary
of State, and director of the new
Walter Hines Page School of International Relations, made the
scheduled address, and the rest of
the program was carried out as
printed in Friday's NEWS-LETTER.
The music was furnished by the
Johns Hopkins' Orchestra and the
ushers were members of the Hopkins R.O.T.C. unit.
Dr. Ames Comments

Dr. Ames, in his brief reply to the
remarks made by Blanchard Randall, speaking for the trustees in
the absence of their president, Daniel Willard, said that he had no
policy of action to outline, no novelties to advocate, and no promises
to make other than not to assume a
presidential attitude.
The president commented on the
spirit of Hopkins, which he defined
as "a consciousness of complete
academic freedom of thought and
action and a common purpose representing the ideals of the members of the facutly." In his judgment, Dr. Ames continued, the
president's first duty must be to
cherish this spirit.
His Purpose

The new president said he
thought the three principal requirements of a professor next to ability
in his field, were character, intellectual honesty, and personality. A
university president, he asserted,
ought to be enthusiastic, and it will
be easy for him to be as ever his
trustee, his faculty and his students.
His only purpose, he concluded, is
to cooperate with these groups to
make the University as great as it
is bound to be.
In presenting President Emeritus
Goodnow for the honorary degree,
Dr. W. W. Willoughby, professor
of political science, called him one
of the most distinguished political scientists of the day, stating
that he was recognized as such not
only in this country but also in
Europe.
The custom, formerly prevailing,
of conferring degrees upon students
at the Commemoration Day Exercises was not followed this year,
it being felt that such action was
more appropriate to the commencement exercises in June.
Speaker Enthusiastic

Mr. MacMurray said the Page
School, because it was attacking a
new field, would have to go slowly,
and might meet disappointments.
On the other hand, he was able to
voice enthusiasm for the work the
institution would do. Although it
may be impossible to hope for the
precision of physical sciences, the
director affirmed, "the very effort
to reduce to priciples the phenomena
of international relationships may
help to bring about a new conception of them . . . . as evolutions
along pre-determined lines.

EDITORIALS

EVENTS OF THE WEEK
EVERAL events of no small importance took place during the past
week-end. Matters concerning the fundamental policies of Johns
Hopkins were discussed by Dr. Ames and Mr. MacMurray at the Commemoration Day Exercises, two Hopkins men, Dr. Goodnow and
Sidney Lanier, were singularly honored, and the new library decorations were formally completed.
Dr. Ames again stressed the spirit of freedom at Johns Hopkins in
his speech at the Lyric Saturday. It has always been the policy of the
administrative officials to allow the members of the faculty to give
their courses in their own manner. Contrast this policy with that of
other universities, which do their best to attract brilliant professors
only to destroy this value by forcing them to conform strictly to
pedagogical principles. Hopkins allows its professors to retain their
individuality, to make decisions on matters which they alone are
qualified to judge, and endeavours to keep the members of the faculty
from becoming mere audible text-books. The restrictive principles
employed by most colleges tends to the treatment of ideas as though
they were parts of a Ford car; all thoughts are carefully examined
by the college officials and, if they conform to pre-conceived judgments, they are stamped "Approved" and allowed to be given to a
bored world. But if, Heaven forbid, some spark of originality should
enter into the minds of a member of the faculty it is promptly and
forcibly extinguished. We should rejoice that Hopkins allows men to
think for themselves and to impart their ideas to others without undergoing the fear of starving their wives and families by so doing.
John Van Antwerp MacMurray, the chairman of the Page School,
outlined the method of study which the school will pursue. Following
the Hopkins tradition, the research plan will be employed. Mr. MacMurray stressed the point that the study of national psychologies will
play a prominent part in the work of the school. The amalgamation
of two social sciences, political science and psychology, studied along
the lines usually reserved for the more exact sciences should prove an
• interesting experiment. The Page School undoubtedly will throw light
upon many of the problems of international relations; its practical
value will depend on to what extent the men who conduct diplomatic
and commercial intercourse between nations will allow themselves to
be influenced by the conclusions reached by the School.
The awarding of the degree of Doctor of Laws to President-Emeritus
Goodnow came as a fitting climax to his career at Johns Hopkins. No
man living has done more for the University; no man has carried out
finer projects at Hopkins; no man could more fittingly be honored by
Hopkins than Dr. Goodnow.

of the neighboring metropolis of
Coopersburg, after suffering for

frat initiates who have seen fit to
possess themselves of his signs. So
now, he has declared that he is determined to prosecute future offenders. "To jail with collegiate sign
stealers!" is the battle cry to be
heard in the highways and byways
of the little town of Bethlehem. The
matter has been referred to the Interfraternity Council and immediate action is demanded. Warrants

of the more active frats fear a

for every Lehigh frat house. We
wish the Crusaders the best of
luck.

Printers

Not a minor item of the book exhibit held last Saturday was the
newly decorated windows of the
Library. These windows, bearing
the marks of famous classic printers were decorated through the bequest of Mrs. Mary King Carey,
widow of Thomas G. Carey in memory of her father, Francis T. King.
King, the subject of the memoriam,
was one of the original trustees of
the Johns Hopkins Hospital.
Numbered from the southeastern
corner of the room, the marked
windows run as follows: 1. Reginald
Wolfe, 2. Sim Vostre, 3. Thomas
Anshelm, 4. Nicolo E. Demenico
Dal Gesu, 5. Simon De Colines, 6.
Louis Elzivir, 7. Andre Wechel, 8.
Johan Froben, 9. William Caxton,
10. Gutenberg, Fust, and Schoffer,
(fathers of modern printing), 11.
Oldus Manutius, 12. Christopher
Plantin, 13. Sebastian Gryphus, 14.
Robert Estienne, 15. Lucas Agunta.
16. Everhardt Ratdolt, 17. Richard
Pynson, 18. Antoine Verard, 19.
Henricpetri.

IF YOU "MAJOR" IN
TRANSPORTATION—
One thing quickly becomes clear to students of transportation
problems.
It is the fact that in large cities the electric car lines with
their auxiliary coach and bus routes form the backbone of
transportation.
In this permanent and necessary public utility the problems
and principles involved are worth the notice and study of
every young man interested in public service.

Track practice was initiated yesterday afternoon when the candidates for positions on this year's
team received their first official
workout on the cinder track. A
majority of last year's men are bask,
there being nine letter men from
last year. Schiebel will not be back
this year, due to the fact that he has
been running for Hopkins for four
years. Two of last year's letter
men have been blacklisted and accordingly will not be able to run.
The prospects are that there will
be a well-balanced team this season
which begins in April. The first
meet is scheduled for April 12,
when Gettysburg will be the opponents. For the last week or so
some of the men have been practicing of their own accord in order
to be in condition earlier.

Swimming Manager
Arranges Schedule
Junior Manager Cone of the
swimming team is arranging the
schedule for next year's natators.
The schedule will cover the months
of January and February, and will
probably embrace eight meets.
There will be one meet the first
week of January and a trip probably to northern territory, the second
week. Activities will be suspended
the next three weeks, due to examinations. During the last three
weeks of February, five or six meets
will be held.

DORM DANCE TO BE
HELD FEBRUARY 28
On Friday, February 28, a
Dorm Dance will be held in
Alumni Memorial Hall. Mike
Romain is in charge of all the
arrangements for the affair,
and tickets may be procured
from him at the price of $1.25
per couple or stag. His postoffice box is 1025.
Quite a number of dorm
students have voiced their intions of attending the dance
and all other students are cordially invited to attend what
promises to one of the most
interesting and colorful dances
of this year.
